sections.markdown:
## Metrics on Grail
* Metrics on Grail enable you to pinpoint and retrieve any metric data with the help of DQL. 
* Metrics can be trended, analyzed, and even forecasted with Davis AI!
* [Metrics on Grail Example](https://docs.dynatrace.com/docs/shortlink/metrics-on-grail-examples)
* [List of Metics on Grail](https://docs.dynatrace.com/docs/shortlink/built-in-metrics-on-grail) or select SUPPORTED IN GRAIL on the metrics screen
![](https://github.com/JasonOstroski/perform-hot24-intro-to-dql/blob/main/images/metricsongrail.jpg?raw=true)

# Exercise 1
1. Fetch CPU load timeseries metric by host

metrics.description: The average number of processes that are being executed by CPU or waiting to be executed by CPU over the last minute

sections.title: Exercise 1.1 - Fetch CPU load timeseries metric by host

sections.markdown:
# Exercise 2
1. Filter on Process group and Host, then trend the CPU load timeseries metric
2. Use Davis forecasting to predict the trend of the CPU load metric
2. Pull data from data explorer and use it in DQL
3. Add "TEST" tag in filter followed by host type

grail.canonicalQuery:
timeseries by:{dt.entity.host, dt.entity.process_group}, avg(dt.process.cpu.usage)
| filter dt.entity.process_group == "PROCESS_GROUP-216FDBEF8325B5C6"
| filter dt.entity.host == "HOST-CD9076CE2003B3F5"

metrics.description: This metric provides the percentage of the CPU usage of a process. The metric value is the sum of CPU time every process worker uses divided by the total available CPU time. The result is expressed in percentage. A value of 100% indicates that the process uses all available CPU resources of the host. It has a "Process" dimension (dt.entity.process_group_instance).

sections.title: Exercise 2.1 - Filter on Process group and Host, then trend the CPU load timeseries metric

grail.canonicalQuery:
timeseries by:{dt.entity.host, dt.entity.process_group}, avg(dt.process.cpu.usage)
| filter dt.entity.process_group == "PROCESS_GROUP-B38B51D78E9FDAD7"
| filter dt.entity.host == "HOST-CCD870C19C09862F"

metrics.description: This metric provides the percentage of the CPU usage of a process. The metric value is the sum of CPU time every process worker uses divided by the total available CPU time. The result is expressed in percentage. A value of 100% indicates that the process uses all available CPU resources of the host. It has a "Process" dimension (dt.entity.process_group_instance).

sections.title: Exercise 2.2 - Use Davis forecasting to predict the trend of the CPU load metric

sections.markdown:
## Exercise 2.3
* Navigate to the data explorer and paste the below metric expression in advanced mode
```builtin:host.cpu.usage:avg:splitBy("dt.entity.host"):filter(and(in("dt.entity.host",entitySelector("type(host)"))))```
* Open with Notebook to build the DQL from the metric expression
![](https://github.com/JasonOstroski/perform-hot24-intro-to-dql/blob/main/images/dataexplorer.jpg?raw=true)

notifications.messageFormat: The function classicEntitySelector() is deprecated and will be removed in the future. To avoid breaking changes in your DQL scripts consider using native DQL functionality instead.
notifications.message: The function classicEntitySelector() is deprecated and will be removed in the future. To avoid breaking changes in your DQL scripts consider using native DQL functionality instead.

metrics.description: Percentage of CPU time when CPU was utilized. A value close to 100% means most host processing resources are in use, and host CPUs can’t handle additional work

notifications.message: The function classicEntitySelector() is deprecated and will be removed in the future. To avoid breaking changes in your DQL scripts consider using native DQL functionality instead.

sections.markdown:
## Exercise 2.4
* Navigate to the hosts screen, add TEST as a manual tag (Key)
* Paste the below metric expression in the advanced mode of the data explorer and open with a notebook.
```builtin:host.cpu.usage:avg:splitBy("dt.entity.host"):filter(and(in("dt.entity.host",entitySelector("type(host),tag(\"TEST\")"))))```

notifications.messageFormat: The function classicEntitySelector() is deprecated and will be removed in the future. To avoid breaking changes in your DQL scripts consider using native DQL functionality instead.
notifications.message: The function classicEntitySelector() is deprecated and will be removed in the future. To avoid breaking changes in your DQL scripts consider using native DQL functionality instead.

# Exercise 3
1. Explore Metrics in Notebook tile! (Currently an early adopter feature, more options to come!)

metrics.description: Percentage of time when CPU was idle during which the system had an outstanding I/O request. It is not available on Windows.
